i was talking about adsl2+ which can deliver upto 20 mega bits per second not mega bytes. if u have a 20 mega bits per second connection u will get 2 megabytes per second and for 100 mega bits per second u get 10 mega bytes per second hence its 5 times faster not 50 i ve got 100 megabits per second fiber optic from virgin uk so i know it for a fact its a ploy used by isp to mention it in meg bits per second.

You guys ALL need to read up on bits bytes and the IEC binary prefixes (which is used here on PB), seriously. Not to mention theoretical throughput on ADSL is just that. Do a bandwidth speed check on a server NOT in your back yard during peak hours and see what you get, its all relative right? Screw what your ISP says.
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mebibyte

You people need to learn the difference between MegaBIT(Mb) and MegaBYTE(MB). There are 8 bits in a byte.

ADSL2+ is 24Mb (Megabit) = 24 / 8 = 4MB/S = 4000KB/S

100Mb (which is what I have in Australia) = 12.5MB/s = 12500KB/s

A little bit of computer 101 right there for you. Learn some shit before you start trolling.

@impulss: You almost got it right, but when transferring files over the internet, there's some overhead, with the net result being that about 10 bits (not 8) are transferred for every byte you receive. The ISP companies will try to fool you that way. A little bit of computer 201 for you.
